China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: School of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan, 411105, PR China. School of Chemical Engineering Xiangtan University Xiangtan 411105 PR China Graphical abstract In this work, an efficient and benign approach for highly selective preparation of cyclohexanone oxime from the liquid-phase oxidation of cyclohexylamine with dioxygen employing supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 as bifunctional catalyst under solvent-free conditions has been developed. The results demonstrated that the bifunctional supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst played an important role in the oxidation reaction, and 31.4% of cyclohexylamine conversion and 83.2% of selectivity to cyclohexanone oxime were obtained over 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3. Moreover, the possible reaction pathway over supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was suggested. It was confirmed that WO3 acted as activating molecular oxygen and the surface hydroxyl groups of γ-Al2O3 were responsible for the adsorption activation of cyclohexylamine. This method for preparation of cyclohexanone oxime from cyclohexylamine is a promising process employing molecular oxygen as green oxidant and inexpensive WO3/γ-Al2O3 as bifunctional catalyst under mild conditions. Keywords Bifunctional catalyst Solvent-free Cyclohexylamine Cyclohexanone oxime WO3/γ-Al2O3 1 Introduction Cyclohexanone oxime (CHO) is an significant organic intermediate in the commercial production of ε-caprolactam, which is used to make Nylon 6, fibers and plastics [1]. The main preparation methods of CHO include “cyclohexanone-hydroxylamine” [2], “cyclohexanone-ammoximation” [3,4], “cyclohexane-photonitrosation” [5], “nitrocyclohexane-partial hydrogenation” [6,7] and “cyclohexylamine-oxidation” [8,9]. At present, most of industrial routes adopt the ammoximation method of cyclohexanone for the production of CHO (route 1 in Scheme 1 ). Recently, with the development of the amination of cyclohexanol and/or cyclohexanone to cyclohexylamine [10–13], the selective oxidation from cyclohexylamine with molecular oxygen to CHO is considered to be a promising process (route 2 in Scheme 1). Compared to the ammoximation route, the molecular oxygen replaces the hydrogen peroxide, which greatly reduces the production cost and danger. Assuming the excellent catalysts in the oxidation of cyclohexylamine can be developed, this method provides a low cost and benign approach for the production of CHO. Recently, some researchers have focused on the selective oxidizing cyclohexylamine to CHO. The oxidizers used in this reaction process mainly involve dioxygen [14–16], H2O2 and alkyl hydroperoxides [17–19]. Among these oxidants, the dioxygen as a cheaper and green oxidizer is more popular in industrial production. Therefore, most of the researches focus on the molecular oxygen as green oxidant employed in this selective oxidation. For the selective oxidation of cyclohexylamine in vapor phase, Armor et al. found that some transition metal oxides supported on silica, alumina or hydrotalcite were effective at 150 °C [20], but the conversion and selectivity are not satisfactory. Kaszonyi et al. reported that the selectivity of CHO was about 70% with 20% of conversion over modified alumina catalysts [21]. Zhong et al. demonstrated the mesoporous SBA-15 catalyst exhibited good catalytic activity [22]. Likewise, the catalytic activity of mesoporous silica gel was also proved by our previous work [14]. In addition, the selective catalytic conversion of cyclohexylamine to CHO in liquid phase was well investigated in the literatures. Klitgaard et al. [23] found the bifunctional gold-titania catalysts displayed the catalytic activity in n-decane solvent. Yu et al reported the selective oxidation of amines to corresponding oximes in the TEMPO/acetaldoxime/InCl3 catalytic system [24,25]. Suzuki et al [26,27] reported the excellent yield of CHO employing DPPH and WO3/Al2O3 as composite catalysts in CH3CN solvent. However, the cost of catalyst and use of solvent, more or less limited their applications in the industrial production. Tungsten-based catalysts also exhibited good catalytic activities on amination reaction [28]. Therefore, developing a simple, efficient and green method for the highly selective synthesis of CHO under solvent-free conditions is highly desirable. Herein, we will report the supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 as bifunctional catalyst for the liquid phase catalytic oxidation of cyclohexylamine with molecular oxygen to CHO in absence of solvent (Scheme 2 ). 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and instrument Cyclohexylamine (AR) and ammonium metatungstate hydrate (AMT, AR) were purchased from Shanghai Mclean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd, China. γ-Al2O3, SiO2, Hβ, MCM-41 and SBA-15 were purchased from Nanjing Micron-nanometer materials Technology Co., Ltd. Other chemical reagents were obtained from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The qualitative and quantitative analysis of oxidation products was performed on GC (Agilent, GC-7890B) and GCMS (Shimadzu, GCMS-QP2010Plus), respectively. 2.2 Preparation procedure of supported WO3 catalysts The supported catalysts were synthesized by impregnation method. Firstly, 2 g of γ-Al2O3 was added to the different concentrations of AMT solution at ambient temperature. Then, the suspension was stirred at 60 °C for 6 h and filtered. Finally, the resulted residue was dried at 100 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 3 h. The samples impregnated with 0.10 g, 0.21 g, 0.41 g, 0.82 g and 1.22 g of AMT were named as 2.5%WO3/γ-Al2O3 (wt.%), 5%WO3/γ-Al2O3, 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3, 20%WO3/γ-Al2O3 and 30%WO3/γ-Al2O3 (wt%), respectively. Likewise, the supported 10%WO3/SiO2, 10%WO3/MCM-41, 10%WO3/SBA-15, 10%WO3/NaY, 10%WO3/HZSM-5, 10%WO3/hydrotalcite and 10%WO3/HY catalysts were also prepared by the same procedure. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterizations of the samples were performed on a Rigaku D/Max-2550VB+ 18KW diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ=1.5418 A) as radiation source at 40 kV and 250 mA. The determination of surface hydroxyl groups of samples were performed on a Nicoletis vacuum infrared system. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurement was performed on a Quantachrome NOVA-2200e at 77K. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of samples were recorded on a ESCALAB 250Xi analyzer using Mg Kα as radiation source, and the binding energy referred to the C 1s peak (284.8 eV). The morphology features of samples were obtained on a JSM-6610LV spectrometer. 2.4 Catalytic performance test of catalysts The catalytic activities of catalysts were tested in a 150 mL stainless steel tank reactor with a Teflon lining. First, the catalyst and cyclohexylamine were added into the reaction kettle, and heated to the designed temperature. Then, the molecular oxygen with constant pressure was introduced into the reactor. The reaction was carried out at set conditions. Finally, after reaction, the qualitative and quantitative analysis of oxidation products was performed on GC and GC–MS, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Comparison on the catalytic performance of several typical catalysts The catalytic performances of some frequently-used and prepared catalysts were tested, and the obtained results were shown in Table 1 . The present oxidation products involved CHO, nitro-cyclohexane (NCH), cyclohexanone (CH), and cyclohexyl-cyclohexylidene-amine (CCA). No oxidation products were obtained in the absence of any catalysts under present reaction conditions. Among these typical oxidation catalysts (NHPI, Co3O4, and WO3), WO3 displayed better catalytic activity. Although some carriers with hydroxyl-surface (such as γ-Al2O3, SiO2, MCM-41, SBA-15 and NaY) also exhibited a certain catalytic activity, the cyclohexylamine conversion and selectivity to CHO were unsatisfactory. Some previous studies had shown that the special structure of WO3 and the surface properties of carriers had important effects on the catalytic performances [29,30]. Therefore, the catalytic performances of WO3 supported on different carriers with hydroxyl-surface (such as MCM-41, Hydrotalcite, SBA-15, SiO2, NaY, HY, HZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3) were examined. The results indicated that the supported 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited better catalytic performance with 31.4% of cyclohexylamine conversion and 83.2% of selectivity to CHO. In fact, WO3 is reportedly able to chemisorb molecular oxygen, and the supports with surface hydroxyl-rich can provide more attachment sites of cyclohexylamine. Through the comparison on the structure differences of carriers, it was found that WO3 supported on some carriers with relatively few surface hydroxyl groups and small pore diameter (such as NaY, HY, HZSM-5 [31,32]) exhibited the relatively poor catalytic activity, while WO3 supported on the γ-Al2O3 carrier with surface hydroxyl-rich and relatively large pore diameter displayed better catalytic performance. These results implied that there was a synergistic effect between WO3 and γ-Al2O3 carrier with surface hydroxyl-rich. Moreover, in order to further confirm the synergistic catalysis, the physically mixed WO3 and γ-Al2O3 were employed to catalyze the oxidation reaction. The results indicated that the conversion and selectivity to CHO were significantly decreased. This fully verified that the bifunctional WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst played an important role in the selective oxidation reaction. Furthermore, the catalytic performances of the existing heterogeneous catalysts reported in previous literatures were also compared, as listed in the Table 2 . Although some catalysts exhibited relatively high catalytic activity, most kinds of them had various disadvantages such as environmentally unfriendly, poor reuse performance, expensive oxidizer, high reaction temperature and use of solvent, which restricted their further applications. 3.2 Comparison on catalytic performance of different WO3 loadings on γ-Al2O3 The catalytic performances of supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 with diﬀ ;erent WO3 loadings were examined in the oxidation of cyclohexylamine, and the results were represented in Table 3 . Compared to pure γ-Al2O3, the conversion of cyclohexylamine and selectivity of CHO were improved remarkably as the supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with 2.5%, 5% and 10% of WO3 loadings were introduced to the oxidation reaction, respectively. However, further enhancing the loadings to 20% or 30%, the conversion and selectivity to CHO presented a descending trend. The possible reason is that the low loading of WO3 particles are dispersed well on the surface of γ-Al2O3, and don’t cover the hydroxyl groups on the surface of γ-Al2O3. Therefore, the appropriate loading of WO3 on the γ-Al2O3 is 10%. 3.3 Optimization of reaction conditions The reaction parameters for the selective oxidation over 10% WO3/γ-Al2O3 were optimized, and the obtained results were depicted in Fig. 1 . It was seen that the cyclohexylamine conversion and the selectivity to NCH and CH increased gradually, while the selectivity to CHO and CCA showed the decline trend with elevated reaction parameters. Our previous works showed that cyclohexylamine could be oxidized deeply to NCH or CH, and CH was further reacted with cyclohexylamine to CCA. CCA could be also oxidized to CH and CHO [14,15] under the suitable reaction conditions. According to our experimental results, the appropriate reaction parameters were that 80 °C of reaction temperature, 1 MPa of oxygen pressure, 5 h of reaction time and 0.3 g of catalyst amount. 3.4 Catalyst characterizations The textural properties of supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, XPS, vacuum FT-IR, Raman spectra, UV–vis and SEM. Fig. 2 depicted the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore diameter distribution curves of samples. The results indicated that all samples showed the characteristics of mesoporous structure [35]. Table 4 summarized the textural properties of samples. It was seen that the specific surface areas and pore volumes of samples gradually decreased with increasing loading of WO3, while the pore diameters were hardly affected. The possible reason was that the excess WO3 particles covered the surface or filled partial pores of amorphous γ-Al2O3 support. The results indicated that the appropriate loading of WO3 was about 10%, and the textural parameters of catalyst showed no obvious change. The wide-angle XRD patterns of γ-Al2O3 and supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were presented in Fig. 3 . Although all samples exhibited the characteristic diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS: No. 29-0063) [36], the diffraction peaks of WO3 were hardly observed under 10% loading, which indicated the WO3 particles had been highly dispersed on the surface of γ-Al2O3. However, 20% and 30% WO3/γ-Al2O3 samples showed evident diffraction peaks at 2θ = 23.2°, 23.5°, 24.0°, 28.7° and 33.6°, which were assigned to (002), (020), (111) and (220) lattice planes of monoclinic crystalline WO3 phase (JCPDS 43-1035) [37,38], respectively. These results indicated that the WO3 was successfully supported on the γ-Al2O3, and the low loading was beneficial to the dispersion of the active components on the carrier. Fig. 4 depicts the XPS spectra of samples. The survey XPS spectra in Fig. 4A shows that the supported 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was composed of Al, W, and O three elements. For the W4f XPS spectra of pure WO3 and 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3 in Fig. 4B, two characteristic peaks at binding energy 36.0 and 38.0 eV were observed, which were attributed to W4f7/2 and W4f5/2, respectively. The difference value of binding energy was 2.0 eV, which are assigned to the W6+ oxidation state [39,40]. As shown in Fig. 4C, only one peak at binding energy 530.5 ± 0.1 eV presented in the O1 s spectra of pure WO3, which was assigned to the oxide ions of WO3 (O–W) [41], and the O1 s spectra of γ-Al2O3 had two peaks at binding energy 531.2 ev and 532.2 eV, which were assigned to O-Al and hydroxyl groups (OH), respectively [42,43]. Likewise, the O1 s spectra of 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3 had three peaks at binding energy 530.5 ± 0.1 eV, 531.2 eV and 532.2 eV, which were assigned to O–W, O–Al and O–H, respectively. Fig. 4D shows the Al2p XPS spectra of the γ-Al2O3 and supported 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3, and the two peaks at 74.6 eV and 75.7 eV were assigned to Al3+ in aluminum oxide (AlOAl) and the electron binding of AlOH [42,44], respectively. These results fully demonstrated that the existence form of WO3 and surface hydroxyl groups in supported 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Moreover, the proportion of the surface hydroxyl groups (−OH) in supported 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was about 17.5% according to the peak fitting calculation from the XPS spectra. In order to further verify the effects of the WO3 loadings on the surface hydroxyl groups, the vacuum infrared spectra of samples were characterized in Fig. 5 . Except WO3, other all samples displayed three main absorption peaks at 3770, 3730 and 3690 cm−1, which were assigned to the alkaline, neutral and acidic hydroxyl groups [45,46], respectively. Moreover, the peak intensities for three kinds of hydroxyl groups were decreased gradually with elevated loading of WO3. Especially, the peak intensities were evidently reduced while the loading of WO3 was exceeded 10%. The probable reason was that tungsten oxides species reacted with surface hydroxyl groups of γ-Al2O3 during the calcination process, which resulted in the reduction of surface hydroxyl groups [47]. Furthermore, the peak intensity of surface hydroxyl groups reduced when the cyclohexylamine was adsorbed on the surface of 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3. The results verified the formation of the H-bonding of the amine to surface hydroxyl groups of γ-Al2O3. However, the three main absorption peaks for three kinds of hydroxyl groups was not obviously observed in pure WO3 sample. Therefore, the suitable loading of WO3 on the surface of γ-Al2O3 was 10%. Fig. 6 displayed the UV–vis spectra of samples. Compared to bulk γ-Al2O3, the supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts display strong UV–vis absorption peaks between 200˜400 nm. Two bands appeared at 205 and 250 nm are assigned to the tungsten trioxide and octahedral polytungstate species, respectivity [48,49]. Moreover, the UV–vis absorption features become strong gradually with increasing WO3 loading. Fig. 7 shows the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of samples. As can be seen, the morphology of bulk γ-Al2O3 is slippy lump. The surfaces of supported samples become rougher and rougher with increasing loading of WO3. The lump morphology can be maintained basically below 10% of WO3 loading. The excess WO3 particles are local accumulated on the surface of γ-Al2O3 as the loading of WO3 increased to 30%. The results indicated that the WO3 particles were well loaded on γ-Al2O3. 3.5 The recycle of supported 10%WO3/Al2O3 catalyst in the oxidation reaction The reusability of supported 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was tested in the selective oxidation of cyclohexylamine with dioxygen. The spent catalyst after reaction was filtered, and then washed with ethanol, dried at 80 °C. The catalyst used for five runs was calcined at 550 °C for 4 h. The obtained results were shown in Fig. 8 . It was clearly seen that cyclohexylamine conversion was only decreased slightly after five runs. Furthermore, in order to further confirm the changes of textural properties of catalyst in cycle process, the BET and ICP characterization results of used and regenerated samples were summarized in Table 5 . Compared to fresh catalyst, only the surface area showed a slight decrease, while the amount of tungsten was basically unchanged. Furthermore, a hot filtration test was performed in order to verify whether the reaction was catalyzed via minute amounts of leached W species. The oxidation reaction was stopped after 2 h at 80 °C and 0.6 MPa of oxygen pressure over 10% WO3/γ-Al2O3, and then the catalyst was subjected to a hot filtration, immediately. The filtrate was continually reacted for 3 h under the same reaction conditions. The experimental results showed that the reaction conversion was not further increased, which indicated the reaction was not catalyzed via minute amounts of leached species. The results demonstrated that 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3 as a heterogeneous catalyst showed good reusability in the selective oxidation reaction. Moreover, the spent catalyst could be recovered by calcination method. 3.6 The possible reaction pathway for the catalytic oxidation of cyclohexylamine with dioxygen over supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 Based on the obtained experimental results and our previous works [14,15], we proposed a possible synergetic catalytic mechanism over bifunctional WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, as shown in Scheme 3 . Firstly, cyclohexylamine was adsorbed on the surface hydroxyl groups as catalytic active sites of catalyst by intermolecular hydrogen bonding. Meanwhile, molecular oxygen was also adsorbed and activated on the surface of WO3 [30,49,50]. Subsequently, two hydroperoxide intermediates could be formed by the NH bond or α-CH bond of activated cyclohexylamine attacked by the activated oxygen. Finally, the formed hydroperoxide intermediate by attacking the NH bond was desorbed from the catalyst surface in the presence of water, and converted quickly to nitroso-cyclohexane by intramolecular dehydration. The formed nitroso-cyclohexane as unstable intermediate was easily rearranged to CHO, and was also oxidized to NCH. Meanwhile, the formed hydroperoxide intermediate by attacking the α-CH bond could also be converted to CH and hydroxylamine [8]. In fact, CH can be also condensed into CCA in the presence of cyclohexylamine. In this process, the supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 as bifunctional catalyst, WO3 acted as activating molecular oxygen and the surface hydroxyl groups of γ-Al2O3 were responsible for the adsorption activation of cyclohexylamine, played a crucial role on the conversion and selectivity to CHO. 4 Conclusions An efficient and eco-friendly method for highly selective preparation CHO from cyclohexylamine over bifunctional supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst under solvent-free conditions had been developed in our present work. The results indicated that supported 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst displayed better catalytic performance. It had been verified that the synergistic effect between WO3 and γ-Al2O3 played an important role in the selective oxidation. WO3 acted as activating molecular oxygen and the surface hydroxyl groups of γ-Al2O3 were responsible for the adsorption activation of cyclohexylamine. In addition, the prepared catalyst is easy to be separated and reused. Compared to the cyclohexanone ammoximation process, the direct catalytic oxidation of cyclohexylamine to CHO is a promising process employing molecular oxygen as green oxidant and inexpensive WO3/γ-Al2O3 as bifunctional catalyst under mild conditions. Maybe this method can also be extended to selective oxidation of other amines to oximes. coredata.dc:description: In this work, an efficient and benign approach for highly selective preparation of cyclohexanone oxime from the liquid-phase oxidation of cyclohexylamine with dioxygen employing supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 as bifunctional catalyst under solvent-free conditions has been developed. The results demonstrated that the bifunctional supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst played an important role in the oxidation reaction, and 31.4% of cyclohexylamine conversion and 83.2% of selectivity to cyclohexanone oxime were obtained over 10%WO3/γ-Al2O3. Moreover, the possible reaction pathway over supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was suggested. It was confirmed that WO3 acted as activating molecular oxygen and the surface hydroxyl groups of γ-Al2O3 were responsible for the adsorption activation of cyclohexylamine. This method for preparation of cyclohexanone oxime from cyclohexylamine is a promising process employing molecular oxygen as green oxidant and inexpensive WO3/γ-Al2O3 as bifunctional catalyst under mild conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Supported WO3/γ-Al2O3 as bifunctional catalyst for liquid-phase highly selective oxidation of cyclohexylamine to cyclohexanone oxime under solvent-free conditions
